People keep saying "If you want something to play until Hades 2 is released, try this"...and they have a point.
"Warm Snow" does have a lot of similarities with "Hades"...and that is a compliment.

In comparison to "Hades", this game is only weaker when it comes to storytelling, but I think partially fault for that is translation.
Everything else is on par with "Hades"...and in some aspects might even exceeds it.

Visual aspect of the game is lovely.
Game mechanics by itself is also simple - melee attack, ranged attack (flying swords) and it's recall (that can trigger a special skill) and ulti attack.

But here is a HUGE twist - melee weapons come in various quality (from common to mythic) and they can also have passive bonuses. You can equip up to four relics (and depending on which position you put them, they can trigger various bonuses and ultimate attacks) that also come in various quality. And you also have perks/traits that you can gain through gameplay (you can choose 1 out 3 offered). This opens almost unlimited possibilities on builds and the most fun aspect is that they can be quite unpredictable (in a good way).
Plus, every time you die, you gain skills points for upgrading three skill trees. Collecting artifacts can unlock permanent bonuses. You can also upgrading your swords in terms of quality and bonuses. And game also offers some additional game modes.

And it will be a challenging game, especially last two levels.

Overall, absolute recommendation for this game and it easily became one of my favorites in this genre and I am looking forward to possible "Warm Snow 2" in the future.

Do you like Hades? Are you bored of Hades and you're waiting on Hades 2? Well, this game has gameplay that's like Hades but it is still different enough to be its own game. I do recommend it and while the lore is nowhere near in-your-face as Hades - especially as the main character is the only one capable of realizing he died -> there is quite a bit of lore going around. Collecting the lore is the gateway to alternative endings and stuff too; there are some non-random specific things you can break -> which drops lore so that's a thing too.

Flying Swords are like casting; relics are like ability boons; skill books are like passive boons; Weapons are "Excaliburs" and there are only swords and one attack pattern for the most part; dashing is the same; and "sheathe" is a dedicated skill that varies. And you can fall down for a few seconds in some situations, usually getting hit, and like Monster Hunter fashion, you're invincible until you get up. 
Also, there are "Sects" which is the closest thing to selecting a weapon in Hades. More on them later.
Fun fact: There are BUILDS you can make based on falling down. They're pretty good. lol


The biggest problem in this game is the inconsistent translations leading to silly things. For example, there's an achievement that tells you to "get both "Indomitable" and "Hurricane" skills at the same time" - but in-game, the names of the skills are "Immovable" and "Galestorm." You can still get the achievement just fine, but know that this extends to the wiki too. This leads to the next problem about this game: information about it is kinda scarce. The wiki has no info on the second DLC and suffers from the inconsistent translation mentioned. 

On the topic of the DLCs, the first one is free and introduces new stuff to play through with new mechanics that adds depths while making you monstrously strong. The second DLC, the one you pay for, does the same but adds more. I do recommend them as they also alter the base game too. 



So, what's good about the game? Well, it plays and handles well and has a decent amount of variety going for it. It's got nice music, a variety of enemies that you can learn to recognize and avoid all their attacks. It's got quite a lot of bosses and minibosses as well as harder difficulties that update boss patterns to make things more interesting - as well as make other things harder in other ways. It's not just number inflation against you.

Generally, you have your weapon and your flying swords behind you. "Excaliburs" can completely change up how the run is going to go. Along side them, you get Relics which are similar to boons in Hades but a major difference: you can swap them around as you please, including dropping them and refining them to boost your stats (mainly: max HP and damage). Then there are "Skills" which can serve as minor little buffs (like, +5% Damage) and go all the way to major game-changing skills - which is usually relevant to your sect.

Oh yeah, there are a whole bunch of "sects" represented by statues -> and you pick one before you get started. Each sect has two styles and some of these are fairly similar but some are completely different. The first sect you start out with is a basic one where you use both your weapon and flying swords without much in the ways of gimmicks. This might sound basic or weak but it is one of the most powerful sects because the lack of gimmicks means one thing: you get stronger by just doing bigger damage. The two weakest sects, in my opinion, are the thunder and ice sects (the fire sect is a bit stronger than them) because you don't start doing bigger damage but instead you do stuff which eventually results in big damage. The early game is a pain for almost all sects but for these two, even the mid-game is a pain for some sects, unless you get lucky.
The thunder sect is more powerful than the ice sect. One style in the thunder sect has end-game where you just dash all the time and killing everything which is crazy fun. 

On a cooldown, you have the ability to "Sheathe." You can reduce the cooldown as your progress to a maximum of 90% reduction (so, most sects will have around 3 seconds total when you max that out). Sheathing is one of the biggest differences between sects as well as styles between the same sect.
For example: the sect with the biggest variation is perhaps my favorite: the Shadow-Walker sect. You lose your flying swords for both styles of this sect but when you sheathe, you summon a flickering shadow that helps you if you pass through it with your ability. 
One style gives you the ability to parry attacks and upon a successful parry, you get some lovely invincibility times and enter "Sheathed" state - where your next attack will be a powerful dashing attack that deals major damage. 
If you sheathe, you enter this state without needing to parry - and if you grab a specific skill -> doing this attack through the aforementioned flickering shadow -> puts you right back into "Sheathed" state. Grab yet another skill and this will also respawn the Flickering Shadow -> meaning you can do it infinitely. End-game here is just hilarious invincibility time while you dash around killing all enemies all the while you make sure you go through the flickering shadow. Dropped it? Sheathe again. Here we go again.
Meanwhile the other style does not have a Parry. Instead, you have a dash attack that deals large damage to enemies along the path and around the area you stop. You start with just 2 dashes that come back after some time and Sheathing gives you a "greater dash" (that isn't effected by the limit of 2) if you go through the flickering shadow -> and the end game is constantly using "greater dash" through the flickering shadow infinitely, killing all enemies. It is the easier of the two and more flexible, but no invincibility. 

The closest thing to easy mode are the two sects: "Infinite Arhat" and the (paid) DLC's "Soul Blade Shura."
Infinite Arhat one has a style called "Sunburst" replaces your flying swords with just one that you charge and fire. With proper timing, you fire a "Sun Piercer" that travels far, pierces through enemies and deals a lot of damage. This allows you effectively kill all enemies before you see any of them. (note: I use controller so unless I'm manually aiming, my flying swords auto-aim at enemies). The sheathe is 5 seconds of guaranteed Sun Piercers, so you can mash to win and by mid-game, you'll have enough sheathe cooldown to have it permanently.
Soul Blade Shura has a style called "Myriad." To simplify it: you sheathe and then you hold down the button for flying swords as you dash through the area. Once you kill all enemies, wait for the cooldown and repeat. Once your sheathe cooldown is low enough, you'll be holding down the buttons for both sheathe and flying sword at the same time as you dash through the game. Forget timing or mashing, just hold them down and keep running.

What about an example for Excaliburs? Well, Sunburst has one called "Fallen Sun" that causes an explosion on a successful Sun Piercer. The explosion hits the enemy and the ones around it for 70% of the damage of Sun Piercer itself. If you hit 3 enemies, that's 3 explosions so each enemy gets hit four times. 
Furthermore, If you have the highest quality (Mythic) Excalibur, then you get a bonus effect. Fallen Sun's bonus effect is to double the damage of the explosion and increase the size of the explosion by 50%. As I said, easy mode. 
There are sect-specific Excaliburs -> and then there are generic ones. Some generic ones work with specific relics and others work with specific skills. 

I didn't even touch on a lot of things, such as unlocks as you progress and the lore. Oh well. In conclusion, I do recommend this game and it's DLC. If you think what I typed up here sounded like fun, give it a go. Have fun.

Late 2023 Edit: With the release of the new DLC, I've gone back and played through it. They've cleaned up a lot of the translation/localization, so it's easier to make sense of things. This did involve some changes to names, but no mechanics actually changed regarding that. This is now much more accessible to an English speaking audience. Also, some balance changes happened, and there's new Statues/Paths to play with, along with relics and weapons. Still a recommend from me. Enjoy!

This game is a lot more engaging than I expected, though before you have any unlocks in the beginning it can be a bit tough--particularly the DLC, since it uses the same permanent upgrades as the main game on top of its own. An inverse bonus is that the DLC can potentially unlock the Blood Soul(?) currency for upgrades at a faster/quicker pace.

I find the art style to be pretty good. Specifically, they really fill out the detail on a lot of stuff in environments, characters, enemies, or the visuals in general.

The only *real* drawback to this game is that the translation/localization is really bad a lot of the time. Sometimes the UI is uncooperative, particularly when doing the DLC and it not allowing you to hover over and check your current textbook buffs. However, some of the skills, debuffs/buffs, and abilities aren't conveyed very well until you actually start playing them. The Supreme Bodhi is a good example, as the translated explanation for No Trace was very confusing until I did a run and experimented with it. Others are how mechanics work, and in some cases there's a lack of explanation. I didn't know you could start with a relic until after I beat the third difficulty and had unlocked quite a bit of stuff already, and further after that I didn't know about recycling extra powers for an attack or HP bonus. I don't really want to fault the game for this, since it's not a native English game. It just means you're going to have to work some things out on your own with experimenting and playing... or read some information online. A lot of the 'older' base content explains things well enough, even the lore, though you'll find a lot of typos and grammatical errors.

There's a big emphasis on choice in builds. The general idea is that your endgame will have you pretty OP once you have a lot of things unlocked, and the higher difficulties are definitely challenging. The DLC is a bit crazier, since some of the bosses are straight up much harder than the main game, and pushing that to finish does require a more cohesive build. I'd say the top difficulties in the main game end up harder, though, since you can't accelerate builds as quickly.

Adding to the above, there's different playstyles between the statues to worship. Most of them have a Melee/Ranged (Flying Sword) option that will focus on a different aspect of your damage. Some will allow you to forgo Melee or Ranged altogether, and Supreme Bodhi is melee focused, but it's a high damage/precision melee that is intended to be less intense and spammy as the others can get. One is built around Poison/Toxin and DoTs. A nice touch is that you can hold down the attack to spam your melee attack. That might seem lazy, but you can get to some absolutely insane attack speed levels that will be impossible to manage with spam clicking. With the Lightning statue I can straight up dip my framerate in the DLC's later stages with a bunch of trigger and lightning effects during Sheathe on a room full of enemies.

As far as performance and bugs go: Overall, I didn't really experience many bugs, and no framerate issues except the above hyper-niche scenario. The only one is the aforementioned DLC issue where I can't check my text upgrades for some reason. Charge enemies, and the "Fish Tail" (high difficulties) that has following ground attacks chain-stunning you off the ground is pretty obnoxious. Sometimes it's hard to spot the suicide stun bots, too, though I can't blame those for ever actually getting me killed. You can play around all of this with a little practice.

Overall, I quite like this game, and recommend if you're into the genre. Like I said: Translation/localization in English is really bad, but other than that I found it to be a good experience overall. The visuals are nice, and generally clean to discern until you get a giga late game build. The bosses are actually wicked, and I was surprised how challenging some could be, and how cool some are. I do dislike Fate Tower, since the Library stages are lacking in detail and variety, often getting the same room format and enemy spawns twice in a row in some runs. Fate Tower's final boss can also drag a bit due to her phase two being time based, rather than exclusively health based. (It speeds up considerably if you run the challenge that causes you to bleed out in combat over time.)

Edit: Typo cleanup, and a bit more praise for the art.

I have finally regained all achievements in this game after the last DLC, unlocked every skin, every upgrade, and gathered a frankly disgusting quantity of time shards or whatever they're called, so I feel ready to say this is possibly my favorite roguelite of all time. It's innovative use of inventory management perfectly balances itself between items, weapons, and passives buffs in a way that feels satisfying both aiming for certain builds or experimenting to see what works. Difficulty modifiers that utilize risk/reward in every step to bring harsh challenges without merely weakening the player to uselessness. The playable classes, or sects as they are called, are all wildly different with their own focuses through unique buffs and what synergies they optimize or even have access to. Seriously, I could write a thousand words on just what each sect excels at and combos with if I thought anyone would read it. The story isn't top dollar, but for a roguelite it's existence at all is something to celebrate. Honestly my only real complaint is that I think there's too many items that focus on defense, in a game where raw strength and massive number clouds is more rewarding than anything else. However, this is thankfully mostly negated with an item-ban system! After getting deep into the game (which is perfectly held off to force new players to experiment and try out all the items before access is readily granted) you can remove them from the pool.
All in all, incredibly strong recommend to anyone who wants fast paced, cathartic action all wrapped up in an acceptable average runtime of about 20 to 30 minutes. But let's be honest, you can never just do one run.

An okayish roguelite but a bit too monotonous to have much replayability. 
Once you complete it with each class and subclass - there's nothing you haven't seen and nothing you haven't done in the game.
And even that feels quite repetitive. Different classes are not so different per se, you have cold/lightning/poison-bleeding damage which are basically different animations that feel exactly the same in the end. You run to a group of enemies or to a boss, hold left mouse button, everything dies, or you shot them from a distance and recall you swords back to you, just dealing different types of damage. This way it feels even less different since in melee you at least have different animations.

Difficulty scaling is absurd and boring. Enemies just get shittons of HP (which feels good at the beginning cuz they just die to fast when you get your build going so you don't feel the difference after getting some near-OP skill). But don't worry, you don't feel that difference at higher difficulties either except that if your build is bad, it'll take a good minute to kill a bunch of normal opponents and much longer to kill a boss, if the build's good, you still one-shot most normal foes, maybe two-three shot more resilient ones and spend about a minute to kill a boss (well, minus the cutscenes and phases of invulnerability). The game doesn't become difficult, it just becomes utterly boring as you do all the same stuff but it takes much longer to kill anything. I've played until Heavy snow, as I understand, there's two more "difficulty levels" but.. What's in it? Just more health for enemies, you hit them, you evade, you kill - nothing new, done it for almost 40 hours now. Still taken down all bosses in practically the same time at "heavy" and at basic difficulty, you push down their health bar in seconds, watch the animation, evade some projectiles/red circles/huge red rectangles, push it down further, evade more stuff and voila - you go to the next chapter. 

Also, it is beyond me why they couln't make boss entrances/changes in phases skippable or faster, same goes for the ending cutscene and the final titles (sure, they are skippable, but you have to hold escape button twice and still spend time for something absolutely useless and unentertaining, gosh I can't even read these hyeroglyphs anyway).

Dream gate developers, for instance, asked their fans to help them translate it. I didn't care to check the translation in-game but all the phrases on the website they used were translated right when I went there to help. Some developers care about their product and find ways.

For the record, I have 393 hours in Hades, half of that before the release, then I started anew to see new dialogues and stuff that was added after. And I still occasionally play it.
This game, on the other hand, has little to no replayability. What a shame for a roguelite.

This game is the perfect formula for roguelite as I like it. You start humbly, with nothing, and try to get as far as you can, then each run you get resources that will make your next run easier.

For each run, you choose the powers of a deity of your choice from among 6-7, then equip a weapon and 4 artifacts and obtain new skills along the way, all with different tiers of rarity. 
If you manage to finish a run, you can increase the difficulty several times, which also increases the drops.
For even more challenge, specific game rules can be activated in exchange for a powerful reward at each checkpoint.

For me, a good roguelite is one that offers plenty of permanent upgrades, and this game doesn't lack any. The skill tree allows you to gain raw stats, or for exemple, to select a legendary artifact at the start of each run, making it much easier to create your build, or to experiment with others without having to wait for randomness to be on your side.
A special store allows you to unlock more bonuses at checkpoints, which are an opportunity to modify your weapon, or gain stats/artifacts or resources.
There are also small gains in stats by completing lists of items to find (lore).

What's more, the free DLC offers just as much content as the base game (it could be its own standalone game), adding special rules and powerful buffs in a new zone separate from that of the base game (in short, at the start of your run you choose either the base game or the DLC).
And even if the two zones aren't connected, the DLC's new special skill tree also allows you to obtain certain upgrades for the base game, a very useful boost for more casual players, or to unlock difficult achievements.
The DLC also adds an infinite mode that increases difficulty as you go along, providing players with both powerful buffs and debuffs, making it a great mode for testing out the strongest builds, as the duration is longer than the basic runs.

In conclusion, I really like these games that offer content accessible to players of all levels.

[h3]Warm Snow is a roguelite with challenging gameplay, a unique flying sword mechanic, and stunning art style. The general xianxia theme is refreshing to see in a roguelite setting. Despite the crippling localization issues that make the game barely legible at times, the fluid combat and build variety still warrants a thumbs-up. Overall Score: 7.5/10[/h3]
[code]

+/- is informational or neutral

[/code]
+ Compelling meta-story that gets an unexpected twist and an ending in the DLC
+ The flying sword mechanic and how each different class/subclass gets different mechanics is particularly well-designed and feels amazing to play with
+ Combat is smooth, fast and responsive. Not much else to say here
+ Wide variety of weapons and relics. There are 50 relics, 51 swords and 7 classes (14 different subclasses) to mess around with. Some swords are subclass-specific swords that massively boost your passives, as a bonus. Many weapons also synergize with one or more relics. Relics have different effects depending on which 4 slots you put them into
+ Meta progression is satisfying and adds new mechanics over time

+/- Higher difficulties practically let you have two orange-grade relics right from the start of a run, which makes it easier to get your build going sooner than later
+/- Free DLC that adds a new game mode with unique Nightmare mechanic. It also adds skins for the NPCs that make them add a bonus effect to their services
+/- You can not turn off the vignette effect. You also can not turn off the "slow motion" effect that occurs in multiple instances
+/- Will take around 30~ hours to get everything including achievements, depending on your luck and how skilled you are. Might take a bit longer if you want the endless mode skins for the 7 classes, however
+/- There are some instant-kill moves, but they are very easy to avoid once you learn about them
+/- You can customize the death message, which is a neat detail

- Different difficulty levels don't add anything other than a massive stat inflation. There are no new mechanics or moves that change how you play the game or fight the bosses. Also, the game is too easy once you figure out what relic combinations work best, regardless of difficulty setting
- Severe localization issues which make a lot of the text illegible. Sometimes they are too long and don't fit where they are supposed to fit, as a bonus. Both of these issues also makes some lore entries impossible to understand. Even a fan would have done a better job when it comes to translating this game, if you ask me. There are also occasional typos here and there. Subtitles (when they exist at all) also are not synced with the voice-over. There is no English voice option, either
- Some classes/subclasses are comparatively weaker while some are absolutely broken even if you don't get lucky with your build
- The skill tree still opens up after every "game over" even if you maxed out everything. I mean, the lady is pretty, but you are wasting my time, game
- Takes time to collect some stuff if you are unlucky. There could have been more "anti bad luck" mechanics overall
- Some transitions and cutscenes can't be skipped, no matter how many times you saw them before
- Some relics feel absolutely worthless, even if they are relevant for some builds (due to better options). Also, most of them synergize with themselves, so you end up getting two of the same relic in some cases
- Difficulty setting doesn't apply to the DLC game mode. This means you can still get lower grade weapons and relics
- You can sometimes get stuck on tiny objects that probably didn't need a collision box to begin with. Looking at you, Nightmare mode torches

The ending in the DLC explains everything and ties in the loose ends, including some of the core gameplay mechanics, like the roguelite aspect. Did you like Hades but thought it needed more sword-throwing? More throwing wine at zombies and setting it ablaze? A frankly preposterous amount of dashing? Then this is the game for you

Warm Snow is a fun take on action roguelike, as mentioned kind of Hades-esque but both more diverse and less diverse in builds somehow. Instead of different weapons at the start of a run, you choose a buddha (kind of like stances? Maybe?), which can significantly alter your playstyle. The "default" is you can slash your blade, throw flying swords into enemies (no aiming, they just find the nearest goon), and do a "sheath" (also called blade call in the translation randomly) to pull the flying blades back, doing extra damage and usually an effect. This combines to be very flashy but simple combat in modestly sized rooms and a bunch of semi-random elements.

The buddha stances range from "normal but you do ice damage" to "you can't throw swords but you can parry" or "your swords are now wine and don't do damage until ignited", there are a ton (oh, let's not forget the infinite-flying-swords that are sometimes lasers one), and there are relics to complement those and many other builds. These are where a ton of the randomness per run comes into play, as you have 4 relic slots and each relic has an effect depending what slot it's in. Also you can have multiple of the same relic.

The other big factor are skill tomes you find, which give you various passive bonuses, usually to damage or defense, but also each buddha has unique ones that crank up the builds.

There are also weapons (excaliburs?) which basically just function as stat sticks - they look quite different but don't change anything besides your damage, and whatever passive effects they give. Again some have unique effects if you have certain relics, or skills, or even a specific buddha, so they can be a big difference, but they feel less "required" than the right relics + skills to compliment your build.

Let me just state up front Warm-Snow is a good game. The art direction,moment to moment combat,customization,and setting are amazing. Though mostly "heroic fantasy" it also has a horror/hopeless desolation vibe that turns the brutality and creepiness up to eleven. If you have also enjoyed titles like Kuon,DreadOut,Nioh,Onimusha,Bloody-Spell,Eastern Exorcist,and Fatal Frame in the past Warm-Snow is very similar with its' visual designs and cultural inflections.

Likewise if you are the type of gamer whom enjoys having access to many different kinds of character builds,customization options,and procedural generated levels with branching paths that occasionally throw in alternate mid-bosses or unique treasures then Warm-Snow is going to be your next obsession for awhile! It is a commendable rogue-like done by developers whom put a lot of love and heart into this project.

As such it is a pity I'm not the biggest fan of rogue-likes. I'm often "suckered in" because on the surface they appear to be satisfyingly visceral and flashy hack n slash action rpgs. The caveat always is the very hard initial difficulty and "starting over from the beginning" upon death just a little stronger than you were before.  

This means you are left re-treading the same scenery and often facing the same enemies. Red exp. crystals which you use to permanently raise buffs,stats,and abilities whilst securing stronger equipment you find in your travels are given to you at a trickle until you defeat one of the "bigger bosses". Don't misunderstand me. This is a power fantasy and "eventually" you will become a war-god! It's just Warm-Snow wants you to grind for it and "earn" your place among the heavens.

The "Enchanted flying-sword style" makes this hero feel distinctly unique. You can do more damage to enemies by impaling them with your floating blades before attacking them in close melee. In an impressive flourish you can call all your swords back to your side and even charge them up with various mystical elemental attributes. It's a welcome change and this basic building block can be expanded upon in unexpectedly devastating ways! (It is possible to become the ultimate enlightened dervish of destruction ascending into speed-running nirvana!)

For 17.99 Warm-Snow is a solid purchase. Just be sure you know what you are getting into as far as rogue-likes are concerned......

Pros

+Game is as beautiful as a painting come to life in all its' beauty and all its' grotesquery.

+Intriguing heroic fantasy/horror setting. (The giant White-Lotus reminds me of The Marker from Dead Space.)

+Moment to moment combat is a visual feast of speed,grace,mystic mayhem,and brutality.

+Plethora of customization/character build options.

+Branching paths with varied rewards and a few alternate mid-boss encounters.

+Interesting challenges for those willing to take on more risks for greater rewards.

+You can pick up your quest from where you quit. Use this strategically because you know what happens when you perish! 

+If you are smart enough and know where to allocate all your relics,bonuses,and skill points you can "break the game" in the best way possible. I've seen this done in play-thrus but I'm still a learning novice.

+Rescued side characters offer up their unique expertise to strengthen your weapons or offer you more gifts and power-ups.

+Sprawling titan-sized ghost-lady merchant will scratch that particular itch!  

+Defeating the main lords unlocks new elemental fighting styles accessed by the increasing prayer statues in the main hub.


Cons

-Excessive grinding

-Upon death you start over from the very beginning

-Red exp. crystals funneled to you at a mere trickle until you have your first major victories.

-Certain bosses have cheap one-hit-kill techniques. (But you can learn to recognize and avoid them even if it is by the skin of your teeth!)

-Despite the "random generation" of locations they still are uniform in theme depending on the area. Aka,don't expect too much variance each time through.

-Repetition. Lots of repetition.

This game is amazing and has so much potential and I dare say at times it's more fun than binding of isaac! Yet it has a few things that prevent me from fully enjoying the game...

I don't know if it's a bug or if it's intended(I hope not).

So bosses will redirect their hits from time to time when you dodge. Basically a well time dodge is not a guaranteed evade. You may still have an attack snap to you and hit you at the end of your dodge animation. This leads to certain mechanics being unavoidable and makes certain "cards" void. For instance having increased dmg while at full health is no longer viable or worth taking because I am guaranteed to be hit at least a few times. 

I believe this is a bug because there are times when I dodge and never have a problem and other times I get hit over and over again. Not dodging any earlier or later then I do. 

That's the only pet peeve I have really with the game. It's this snappy hit reg mechanic that is really nice because it makes the game harder and in turn fun to master. Punishing you for dodging to early and yet I can't help but feel it's a bit wonky when you are hit because you dodged a literal millisecond before the attack animation. Meaning the boss snaps to you and attacks you at the end of your dodge animation sometimes waiting for your dodge animation to end(or at least it appeared like that). Since most attacks are fast so when an attack looks longer than usual it is kinda sus.

Serious I have had attacks that normally should be dished out within a second not be thrown out and hold that attack for another second while I finish my dodge animation just to then throw the attack and hit me. Serous sometimes you feel as if the programming is predetermined to hit you at times. I don't like that not one bit!

Of course I don't really know what's going on. I really enjoy the game as I stated above and I prefer this game over the binding of Issac to be frank. It's got depth and both games are fun but this is definitely more my style of game.

A simple fix to that problem stated above(it is a problem) is to indicate attacks using the red and white lines. Even having a better indication of the attack... have the arm or weapon follow the player until 0.2-0.5 seconds or whatever(more clear animations). Then stop the arm or weapons whatever in place. Meaning the attack no longer tracks the player. 

That's what is really key here. There needs to be a clear point in time when the attack no longer tracks the player and it needs to be visibly clear so players can pick up and learn the queues. That's what makes games like these fun to master.

I really want to sink hours into this game but it's really turning me off and slowly diminishing my will to play the game. I mean we are talking if I knew these mechanics were present in the game prior to playing. Just for those reason I would of been more likely not to purchase the game.

I want to give this a thumbs up but if you have mechanics that ruin the experience and burn players out early on. Then I can't exactly give this game a thumbs up.

So... the base game is fun, and I like the variety of builds that are actually different. But there are several glaring problems with this game that makes it questionable as of this moment.  

1. Terrible difficulty scaling. The enemies and  especially bosses scales way too hard for the higher difficulty to a point that is not fun to play. A great example would be the 2nd boss. In lower difficulties you can finish her first phase in less than 5 mins. On the 2nd highest difficulty it took about good 10 mins with one of the highest dps builds I could make. And don't even get me started on the last boss, which is about 20 mins of repeating the same patterns. It got so bad that I actually fell asleep for when I was fighting the 3rd boss, luckily I woke up in like 2 seconds and pause the game. Still, falling asleep while fighting a boss should never happen in a game. My runs now consistently goes from 90 mins to 2 hrs. And that's from the 2nd highest difficulty. The runs on the highest difficulty will be even longer.

2. Some builds are too weak. It's a balancing issue, that some builds are just easier to beat the game than others... well at least they can do it much faster/safer. 

3. Too many set pieces for bosses moveset. Like the last boss, he'd do a move in his last form trying to suck you in, and then if you escape, you'd be fine. The problem is this move takes forever, and it's really not a challenge... so it just becomes a time sink. You'd see him repeating the same move - and I'm not exaggerating - more than a dozen times in the fight. You only have so much of a window to burst him down when you can, and then he goes back to repeating the same cycle again. It's stupid and a waste of time. IMO the boss should only do that move once to signal that he's in his last form now, and then go on to do other moves.

4. Hard to read what's on the screen for some builds. I like melee builds, but some of them you literally can't see your character nor the enemies since the special effects basically cover everything. Like using the electric melee build to call down thunder - I can't see where I am or what my character is doing or even what I'm hitting or what's hitting me. At that point I'm just going off intuition but honestly this should not happen.

5. The bosses get boring after the 5th playthrough or so.  

If you think you'd only play this game at the first 2~3 difficulty, go ahead. It's quite fun that way. But as you go up in difficulty, it quickly becomes more unfun because the way the devs think difficulty works is by making everything a sponge without adding any new elements.

Legit one of (if not the best) live-the-life-of-a-wuxia-protagonist game I've ever played. If you ever read a wuxia story and imagine what it'd be like to throw swords around and slash like crazy, this game's pretty much for you. It fulfills that one fantasy, unlike most other games like it that spread around a bit, but it fulfills it perfectly. As many reviewers pointed out, it's quite similar to hades, but I'd argue a bit higher paced, if less varied. 

Note that the balancing isn't the greatest, and that you progress through the game fairly quickly--but I actually enjoy these two points, especially having gone into the game blind. Stumbling onto an insanely oppressive build that was finished 2 stages before the last was extremely fun, and just playing around with various possibilities is equally so. If you're an end-game purist, perhaps these balancing nods might piss you off, but I mostly play for the entertainment and usually stop once I've hit that 'play for 200 hours' wall, so this is perfect for me. 

If you want a game where you can dump around 30-40 minutes a night into and have a blast, this one's for you. Runs can go on a bit longer at a higher difficulty, especially if you don't get a good roll of luck early on, but oh well, you can always restart. 

UI's a bit wonky at times as it clearly wasn't optimized for English language so sometimes you'll see words bleed beyond the border, but they are relatively rare. Anyway, if you're a fan of fast-paced, Hades-like games, this one's for you. Plus, if you ever wanted to feel what it would be like to take upon the mantle of a wuxia MC, look no further. Slash away and all that jazz.

The game feels really smooth and very satisfying to maneuver and fight in. My pros heavily outweigh the cons and have had  a lot f fun exploring different build paths and items. I'll list a couple specific pros and cons for anyone who might be interested or is new to the game. 

Pros:

-Variety: I have just over 20 hours and I feel like I haven't had any two builds be the same. With all the different weapons and relics, all with color coded tiers, modifiers, and attributes that are randomized (on weapons), the game feels like ther is a never ending combination of things to play with. To top it off, you get to eventually choose a bunch of different things to use before you even start the run so you don't feel like your success is completely rng based.

-Combat: The combat feels very crisp all from lighting fast, meat slapping atk and mvmt speed to slower but hard hitting curb stomping damage. Throw in a bunch of debuffs and status effects and you got yourself some very powerful feeling slicing and dicing.

Cons:

-Dialogue/ Narration: This game does not have english narration which isn't a huge issue, just would be nice to know what characters are saying without having to read speech bubbles. The real con here is the translation in item descriptions are not super accurate and sometimes it takes some depicting to figure out what it says, or doesn't even finish the description at all.

-Terrain: I really like all the little things they put on the floor to add to the density of the stages, but it's infuriating when there's a bunch of stuff going on and I get stuck on a little book or something and end up taking a bunch of damage, or sometimes the character stick to walls in very odd ways and have the same conclusion.

Overall:
Very fun game and plan to put many more hours into it :)

It's missing some key quality of life items for me:
1.  You can't use arrow keys to move.  Games that have WASD allow us left-handers to use arrow keys also, or otherwise allow key rebinding.  Dev said they would look into adding it in a January 2022 comment, but seems they haven't bothered in the end.
2.  No 'gore off' option.  Everyone you kill leaves a huge splat of blood on the ground.  I like to reduce gore when playing because my youngest son will often watch me play games.

Aside from that, I wasn't keen on the item matching bonuses.  This card does X effect if you have exact Y card.  This feels pretty restrictive.  Normally it would be you get a bonus if you have Y type of card to allow more open synergies, not naming a single specific card you have to come across.

On the plus side, I did like that you had a range ability by default in addition to melee ability - although so many effects were focused around 'if you do a melee attack after a ranged attack' or vice versa - so the game was heavily pushing that I had to use both rather than letting me focus on one.
I also felt that the roguelike permanent progression was somewhat attractive to keep me playing, although fairly basic benefits.

[h1] A Unique and Fun, Albeit Flawed, Isometric Roguelite [/h1]
[i] My progress as of this review: I have cleared 3 difficulties. [/i] 

[b] My pros: [/b]
[list]
[*]The combat feels good when you're attacking. It feels very impactful and quick, the movement is smooth, and you have a lot of attack and movement option. 
[*]The building is fun and there are a lot of choices to make. 
[*]The initial difficulty is extremely approachable. My first clear was 4h into my playtime. There is also no artificial gate or meta-progression preventing you from beating this game on your first attempt, which I see as a win. 
[*]Ghost lady booba
[*]The meta-progression is meaningful. You can actually feel the effects of your progression and there is not an excessive amount of grinding required to complete your tree. 
[*]You can quit and return to where you were in the middle of a run. This is a great QoL feature that some roguelites don't include, but as a father this is very important to me. 
[*]Beautiful hand-drawn art and awesome particle effects. 
[*]Good sound design, music isn't memorable. 
[/list]

[b] My Cons: [/b] 
[*]Excessive knock-downs from enemies. A lot of the time this CC will come from offscreen or an enemy will rush you with not nearly enough time to react. This issue is only exacerbated as you progress through the difficulties. 
[*]Lots of choices, but not all choices made equal. I feel pretty confined as to what I can build or what God I can start with. Some just feel straight up useless. 
[*]HUGE ramp up in difficulty in the final area. You may think you have a fantastic build going only to find out the sponges in the final area take 2 full minutes to kill and hit like a semi. 
[*]Too few i-frames. Especially considering some enemies have attacks that have very small dodge windows. Fighting the concubine is an absolute slog because of this, unless you have a broken build. There is an item to increase the i-frames, but I feel as though they should just fix the dodge by adding innate i-frames..
[*]Unskippable boss cutscenes. Every time I get to the bosses I have to watch an unskippable mini-cinematic that I've already seen 10 times. It just adds unnecessary time to runs and gets annoying. 
[*]If possible, combat clarity needs work. A lot of the time I find I'm just face-tanking without realizing because I can't for the life of me see what the hell is going on behind all the particle effects. 
[*]Lu Kunhai auto-fail mechanic. No. Just no. Remove it. If you have the indomitable perk it makes this fight literally not possible to complete unless you react 3 seconds in advance to a randomized moveset. Also, indomitable sucks, please fix. 
[*]Enemies get very spongey later on, and without a crazy build you will be trudging through an absolute swamp of HP trying to get to the end. I've had several runs I just straight up reset because I was on the final stage and healthy but didn't want to spend the ridiculous amount of time it would take to whittle down the enemies and bosses. 

[b] TL;DR - It's very fun but has its share of flaws. Overall, I'd say the pros outweigh the cons here and I'd recommend it. I'm sitting at just over 20hrs and planning to put plenty more in. [/b]

But for the most Part every Item is understandable enough to play it.

And third, there are a lot of reviews about a Bug with the first Boss being invincible, as far as I can tell that has been resolved a long Time ago.

All in all I'd say Warm Snow is a nice Rouge-lite experience, that has a multitude of Factors that can alter your run, most and foremost Sect's (Scrolls) that provide passive Bonuses, but the Weapon of Choice also has a huuuuge effect, specially on 'Classes' that have a Signature Weapon that's benefits them most.

The thing I found most interesting were the Relics, Items that provide Bonuses depending on where in the four Slot 'Inventory' they are placed, the huge thing that can easily be missed/underestimated is, you can always reallocate the Relics order, to adept the effects to new Relics or a new weapon/sect you found along the way.

Coming to the Classes, each run you choose one Avatar which provides a General passive and a secondary playstyle defining passive of two Options. At the start you only have 1 Avatar to pick from, with 6 when you unlocked all of them trough Gameplay.

All in all the Game isn't that long, one run on average took me one Hour, so it lives from repeated Playthroughs, for which you have 6 Classes (12 if you count the Subclasses), and 6 Difficulty Levels.
Apart from the First and last Act, all Acts consist of multiple Loots Areas, a Mini Boss and an Act Boss, while there is a pool of 2 to 3 Minibosses per Act, the Act Bosses are always the same.

The great thing about the Difficulty design is, that at first all Acts are separate, which each Difficulty bleeding the Enemy Types and Mechanic over into all Acts when you hit Difficulty 5 (Blizzard).

The Final Difficulty (White Ash) where you can obtain Master Skins for each of the 6 Classes by playing trough with them is basically identical with Blizzard except that all Act Bosses (and some Mini Bosses) have an additional 'Move' which makes the Fight quite different, especially for Melee Focused Classes (only beat it with a ranged Class yet).

This game is incredible, the power fantasy is extremely strong, and it isn't afraid to let you run away with a specific build.  It definitely feels like the game is trying its best to make me as strong as I possibly can.  The balance seems very good, and it's extremely nice that the base difficulty isn't balanced around any meta progress updates.  After beating the Chapter 2 boss who seems like a skill and DPS check wrapped into one, on my third run I was able to face tank my way to the end of the game.

Now for the bad: the localization is awful, some dialogs have absolutely no translation at all, and some pretty major bugs exist with only potential workarounds.

That being said, I 100% recommend giving this game a try, especially if you're a fan of "Hack and Slash" style gameplay.

EDIT: Officially beat all the content the game has to offer, and I have a few edits to the review but for the most part everything holds true, although most of the major bugs have been fixed.  Difficulty scaling seems largely just be "more bullet sponging" and while it makes you feel phenomenal when you finally crack the curve, the final difficulty mode [spoiler] Blizzard [/spoiler] feels kinda rough.  Although, I really like the increased minimum rarity that comes with the difficulties, as it really lets you push builds to their limits.

The unlockables definitely need some more thought, as I finished the final difficulty before I even managed to unlock the last playable character or unlocked all the hidden stories (Which are an awesome part of the game).  Also, the meta currency could use some in-game uses, as once you've maxed out the skill trees, it's essentially useless.  The NPCs are great and I love the new Blacksmith NPC conceptually, although I'm not a huge fan of the implementation of the sword upgrade feature as the chance to upgrade to impossible feels too low on high difficulties.

Localization is still bad, but its definitely getting better slowly.  I'd really like to see the distillation dialogs fixed, and the text runoff on the item dialogs is really difficulty to play around, and it feels like a lot of the difficulty in item selection is based on trying to parse out how certain interactions might work together on the fly from poorly worded text.

Also, when you sects that render other sects completely useless, it would be nice if those were removed from the pool of items.  It can be a bit disappointing when you've taken a sect that removes your dash, only to be presented with a longer dash or longer invincibility after dashing as your sect choices.

Generally speaking though, the game is incredible with tons of replayability and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a great Hack n' Slash roguelite!  You can easily get a few hours out of the game, and the devs are actively supporting the game which makes it much easier to recommend.

Overall, a very fun roguelike to scratch that Hades itch. A good variety of unique aspects with cool specializations, and some really fun options to choose for relics. I thoroughly enjoyed playing through most of the game.

With that being said, as I push through Snow Storm and Blizzard difficulties, I'm not enjoying it nearly as much.

Now, it seems that the massive increase in monster health is supposed to be offset by the higher chance of epic and legendary item drops, and impossible Excalibur drops. And some of the special mods that the legendary relics have are really awesome. But in the end, it realllllly falls flat on feeling "good". The monster HP scaling is absolutely off the charts, and I have yet to see a build that really counters that.

My last run was on Snow Storm difficulty. I played the blood aspect with a legendary Bruise Herb in my skill slot, so I had insane healing. I was largely unkillable. My other 3 slots were filled with legendary Hydrargyrum in the Core and Power slots, and a legendary Poison Sac in the agility slot. I was never offered a zombie finger, as I think that would have been the only saving grace for my damage if I was able to get a legendary zombie finger in my skill slot for additional stacking. Every normal room was fairly quick and entirely effortless, and every boss took ages. The final boss took about 10 minutes to kill, and I was at absolutely 0 risk of dying at any point of the fight - I ended it with full hp and didn't use a single flask all run. Since I had the bruise herb fully sustaining me, I took every single damage buff offered....and I still felt like I had no damage. To me, that isn't "fun". That felt like a but of a god run, but I left it feeling super weak. Oh, also the alternate ending choice after the final boss bugged out on me and disappeared so I was stuck in the boss room. I had to save&exit and restart only to slog through the boss a second time for another 10 minutes. That sucked.

Also, there is the meta upgrades.. I already have the entire meta tree allocated, and another 50 some coins for it. I feel like it maxes out far too quickly with nothing else to spend the upgrades on. Some of the meta upgrades are really cool and useful, but if you can max it before even unlocking Blizzard difficulty, theres not much point in pushing further is there?

So at this point I am tempted to go back to the Fine or Medium snow difficulties just so its not a slog fest to complete a run, yet I want to play with some of the unique legendary and impossible items that are super rare at those difficulties. Kind of just leaves me with a sour taste in my mouth.

I am nowhere near beating the game -- just managed to get to the end of the second chapter, and the second major boss... but my God is it amazing.

Two major things:
-build variety (each new statue/class creates A LOT of possibilities and synergies, and most of them are hella fun in their own way. it's not easy to keep the game challenging while also constantly creating the feeling that your character is OP, but that's exactly how I feel almost every run);
-convenience and flexibility (for example, changing the position of your relics on the fly? easy! don't commit to shit, improvise and have fun!)

It also has a lot of flavour. I do love me some super-Chinese games -- and one part of it is definitely because I lie to myself thinking that playing it helps a bit with my very rusty Chinese... but if you're looking for something very fresh and chunky, lore-wise, this game'll be right up your alley.

also, if you love wuxia stuff, this game is cocaine.

EDIT: just got to the ending for the first time, with a build so OP that even the heavens looked at me with nothing but disgust. It was glorious.

If you're looking to scratch the itch Hades left because you've played too much of it, this is for you.

This is the Hades successor I've been waiting for, at least in terms of gameplay.

If you enjoyed the core mechanics of Hades, you'll likely enjoy this too. You start runs by choosing what is essentially a class (think a weapon in Hades), then fight through levels, picking which path to take to earn different weapons, or skills, or heals etc. It'll feel very familiar to Hades players. The controls are very responsive, and I've never had a death that I felt wasn't my own fault.

The story and world aren't on the same level as Hades, but what is? The story is pretty basic and simplistic, there just to drive the game forward rather than deliver a compelling narrative.

There are a couple of issues, though; 

First, the translation is really lacking, or outright missing, in places. Some things aren't translated at all, including boss dialogue and some on-screen alerts in the "base" stages. There are also typos all over the place.

The other major issue is poor information presentation. This comes in a few forms; some information is too long for the box it's meant to fit in and overflows or gets cut off, especially with high-rarity weapon stats & info. There are also some descriptions which just don't make sense thanks to poor translation, and it's also really difficult to compare the effect of different weapons/skills etc, because there's no place to just see your actual stats like damage output etc. That makes it pretty tricky to plan out a build or really figure out if a change will be a positive or a negative.

It wouldn't take much to fix these issues, so hopefully it's something the developers will address quickly.

That being said, if you can put up with the janky translation and having to figure out what some things do on your own/using the steam community, and you liked Hades and want something familiar but fresh, I highly recommend this game.

Overall, an exceptionally addicting game. 

The movement and combat is exceptionally clean & tidy, and extremely satisfying. The game design & lore collectables add a real nice unexpected bonus, and the skill tree feels exceptional - putting points, even early, in the trees gives you real tangible benefits.

The seperate classes are very interesting and enjoyable. I've played with at least one of each style, and they all change things up enough to really transform how you play the game & consider your relic/elixir choices.

The rarity tier system feels like a real treat across all aspects and the unique modifiers the Legendary ones provide turn some relics from an instant-skip to a won-run - one of my favourite items I located was an Impossible Ordinary sword, which had a 1/10000 chance of instantly killing everything on screen with every attack under the debuff known as 'Programmer's Rage'. Was fun to see.

However, it's not all good. Here's a short list of issues with the game currently.

* Spelling errors & typos in transaltion - many elements of the game aren't even translated at all, and while that could be purposed as flavour in some games, it's missing in several important aspects here where the game is trying to convey vital information to you without you being able to understand
* Lack of a simplistic stat sheet. Although there is a help menu that explains what each of the conditions do, there's no way to see your current movespeed/crit%/Flying Sword DMG etc etc and I feel the game would really benefit from this clarity
* In another vein on transparency & translation, many skills will tell you there's a 'chance' of something happening without in fact telling you what that chance is. 
* The harder difficulties are an excellent way to step things up - HOWEVER, unless you're running two very particular builds, certain zones are full of bullet sponges - it took me 20 minutes to kill the Concubine on higher difficulties with Infinity & at several points I considered just letting her kill me after watching her jump up the the ceiling for the 100th time. Admittedly, this is likely a skill issue - if you know you're on a hharder difficulty, force a specific build.
*The runs are LONG. Even with a god-like run you can be playing for hours before you get to the final boss. Now admittedly, I play games like Noita so I'm no stranger to throwing hours into a run for purely prep work, but in a fast-paced hack & slash this can be really noticeable after Chapter 3. If you're looking for a rewarding quick dip-in-dip-out game, this isn't it.

With all that said, that may cast a rather negative light on this game. But no, even despite all it's flaws, it's a solid 8 or 9 out of 10. Rewarding, addictive, satisfying.

If you're a fan of snyergy-heavy roguelikes in the vein of Hades or Dead Cells, you'll enjoy this game. Straight up.

Is it perfect? Absolutely not. It's extremely messy currently. The translation is spotty at best (literally in many cases, as some of the subtitles are in English, and others are in Chinese, and not every voiceover has even an attempt at subtitling), the tooltips are sometimes far, far too obtuse (things like mechanics not being explained, probabilities for something to occur left completely open-ended, etc.), there are definitely still bugs, and there is a suspiciously large number of visuals/themes that are lifted from pre-existing games.

But it's honestly just fun to play. The synergies and scaling build really fast and hard, which makes progression very exciting, and there are a TON of different ways you can build that can all be successful. There is a simplicity to the actual play that some may not appreciate, but it works perfectly for me. As it stands, you have either 3 or 4 abilities to utilize at any given time. I prefer it that way, personally, but I can see where others would prefer more. I actually tend to opt specifically for the builds that eliminate the 4th button because I would rather focus on other things.

The enemies and abilities are complex enough to be challenging in a lot of circumstances (nearing bullet hell levels in a lot of cases), but not so punishing that you have to slam your head against the same boss for hours at a time. I finished my first run about 5 hours into playing, and I'm not the best roguelike player around by any means. Don't let that make it sound too fast or simple, though; I had only unlocked 2 of the 6 base builds at that point, and full clearing only unlocked 2 more of them. There is a ton of replay potential. Maybe not as much as Hades or Dead Cell, but still plenty to keep you entertained for only $18.

For story, it's a complete fail. The obtuse translations that do exist are nowhere near enough to give you even a clue what's going on, the voiceovers aren't translated, and it has the sort of barely coherent, hazy storytelling that is typical of Chinese high fantasy (think Wuxia movies) and that can make it difficult to understand even when the translation IS perfect, which this is clearly not. Buuut you don't always need that much story in a mechanics-heavy roguelike anyway, so it doesn't really bother me.

Die-hard roguelike players: 7/10, definitely worth buying, and has 8 or 9/10 potential with fixes and refinement
General gamers: 6/10, maybe wait for the rest of the bugsquashes and translations to be finished, but you also won't be completely disappointed if you try it now.
Casual gamers: 3/10, nah. The issues with the game can make it very, very confusing if you're not the type to dig into these kinds of games on the regular, and there is 0 comprehensible story to fall back on.

Now that ive cleared the game on every difficulty and unlocked everything i feel like its time to review this game. Il start by simply saying that for the price, this game is well worth it - but i will probably never return to this game again, and the reason for this is that the devs have no idea how to handle difficulty.

I wont get into the sounds and looks of the game since frankly, you can judge them for yourself in the trailer above here. I personally found the look really neat, but the music boring and standard - you make up your own mind.

Let's start with the good stuff;

The combat during the first 3 difficulties feel smooth and fun, something akin to a faster-paced Hades where the attackspeed is counted in nano-seconds instead of attacks per second.

The ability to have 6 different "classes" or builds or whatever you wanna call them with 2 variations of each at the beginning feels great aswell (the first 3 difficulties) 

The different items or "relics" or "elixirs" (depending on where in the game you read about them. Their translation isnt up to snuff yet.) have a really cool feature of doing different things depending on where you equip them - giving the same item different uses with different builds. They also vary between synergising with a specific build or with itself in some cases - so having 4 of the same item isnt always a bad thing.

The weapons, or "excaliburs" as the game calls them, are also pretty nice with cool random buffs and each weapon having a synergy with either one passive skill or item in the game, making it feel really neat when you just happen to find a weapon that synergises with your items or choice of passives.

The meh stuff;

The bosses. 
The ones that dont just run up to you and hit you or put down the big "Dont stand in the fire" attack instead have these invulnerable states that pose no threat and merely adds to sinking you down. The last boss on the final difficulty is a nightmare due to him going invulnerable every 10 seconds and doing this "dangerous" super attack that you can literally always walk away from with no threat to you whatsoever, all it does is stop the game for 20 seconds and then allow you to keep hitting him - more on this particular bastard below.

The enemy variations.
The enemies are fairly few and where there is some difference you quickly realise they are just skins. and later in the difficulties all enemies are showing up in all different locations causing the variations to become even more repetetive.

The really really really BAD;

The fucking difficulty.
Jesus H Christ the difficulty. 
This game is NOT a hard game, its just a VERY taxing game. il try to explain - The difficulties dont really add more difficulty, all they do is beef up the enemies hp and armor. 
The bosses gain no new mechanics, just ALOT more hp and armor, making you able to easily evade everything they throw at you but instead deal 1% damage every few seconds or so ending up taking time and not skill to beat.

The regular mobs gets the same treatment and in the last difficulty just clearing an area can be you permastunning every single mob on the map and doing thousands of damage per second to them with no threat to your life whatsoever - you will just feel the slog as you slooooooowly drain away their hp.

Then you will have the CC immune mobs that wont stay still when you hit them and jump around making it take even longer. 

They also add some demon-fish tentacle that spawns every 30 seconds or so, on the 4th difficulty 1 pops up and the last difficulty 3 of them pops up at the same time - this once again IS NO THREAT. it merely forces you to run around for abit wasting even more time to an already EXTREMELY slow gameplay pace that wont threaten your run in the least.

And the final nail in the coffin and main-reason to why im so burned out on this game. The final, fucking, boss.

The only reason i stuck around long enough to kill him is that Roguelikes and roguelites is my cocain. I need to clear them to move on - and boy, i HATED the last couple of hours in this game due to the fact that i knew this guy was coming up.

The first 75% of his bar isnt a problem, he stands there and you swing at him, unmolested for about 10 minutes. 
then he reaches his 25% mark and decides that enough is enough. 
He then starts calling down aoe attacks on the ground, basically all the time - these in turn occasionally turn into poison pools that apply a debuff to you that deal more damage the longer you fight him. 
Then every 10-15 seconds he turns invulnerable, teleports to the middle of the arena and teleports you in there with him, he then begins charging some doom-attack which you can easily walk out of and then he continues to rain down poison pools and rince repeat forever.

Doesnt sound so bad, the thing is - these pools NEVER go away. so pretty soon the entire arena will be filled with this extremely damaging aoe fields. and youre still doing 1% every few seconds with him going invulnerable for his attack every 10-15 seconds. Btw, this whole thing clocks in at about 10 seconds - so thats you not being able to hit him in a field of poison every 15 seconds for 10 seconds. 

This boss is only a DPS check and this wouldnt have been a huge problem if it wasnt for the fact that the devs went haywire when it came to adding armor/hp buffs on the enemies. were not talking x10 or something, more like x50 (im not even kidding). 

Killing this guy was not fun. I didnt feel "yeah, take that you asshole, now to try another build" - i felt "finally, now i can play something fun."

Ending this slog of a difficulty with a boss that essentially is only a dps test is the worst idea imo.

This coupled with certain items just not working against bosses makes you really have to plan your builds instead of making do with what you get - and that goes against what i like with Roguelites. All together with the difficulty only being artificial to certain builds just not working at all, to boring harmless meatwalls called bosses standing in your way to the only real threat which is the final boss (or possibly the tiger-lord in the room before him) just makes me soured on the whole game.

Im sure there are some people with more addiction than me that loves this aspect of hitting the same target for an extended period of time with no threat to themselves, but personally i prefer the difficulty of games like Hades that add things other than just massive HP to the enemies.

In Hades ive unlocked and done everything and I still come back to it just cos the gameplay loop is fun, its challenging and im still enjoying it.
This game? Ive gotten every unlock and cleared all the difficulties - I cba to get the secret ending, I just dont want to play it anymore.

I still recommend it for the price though, seriously good price.

[h1]THE UNPOLISHED HADES[/h1] 

[b]It's fun, it has potential[/b], but damn it is unpolished, and i have a lot of criticism for it. 

You can read up on other reviews for pros, I'll elaborate on criticisms here. 

Here you build your characters using Relics, Sect Skills, and Excalibur(weapon). You can only equip max of 4 relics, but you can keep on piling Sect skills, and equip only 1 excalibur. 

In most roguelike, you constantly build your hero till the endgame, every upgrade is additive and gives you the incentive to look for a certain build, not here. The problem with relics is, there are tons of variety, probably 15+, but they don't sync with each other, and here's the deal, everything you get is totally random. So essentially you get your 4 relics very soon but in the later stages, they keep on giving you relics as upgrades, which is totally useless. 

So imagine in Hades, if you get Zeus boons, you know they'll have more Zeus boons later on so that you can build it up and hopefully land that ultimate Zeus boons, and that they limit it so that you have only 4-5 gods' boons appear in 1 playthrough. But here, imagine you get Zeus boons, but there's 15+ other gods' boons that appear that doesn't sync with Zeus, and that you might get Zeus once....and never again.

Imagine in Hades where you can buy different boons, but any boons you buy adds to the character, here the shops sell you 4 relics, but if you have equipped 4 of them, essentially all the shop items are useless, because you have to replace your existing relics.

Then you have your weapon. Some high tier weapons have bonuses if you have 2 specific relics, but the stupid thing is, those 2 relics may never appear in you entire playthrough, so you can't prepare for any build and rely purely on luck. The only thing that keeps on upgrading is Sect skills. I have tons more criticism but I'll probably write it on the discussion forum. 

Also, some people say there's tons of playstyle variety...I tell you honestly..NO, there's only 2, close or range. There's no animation differences to all the weapon, no length no width differences. All the different builds amount to the starting area where you can choose whether you want your weapon to deal fire/ice/lightning/poison damage etc, or you can choose that your range is now more powerful. Don't expect anything like Hades or Devil Slayer:Raksasi where you have different weapons and they work differently.

It's still fun, and I want to support the developers, but it's so unpolished. If Hades is diamond, Warm Snow is still carbon.

This game is OK. I'm recommending it, but you probably want to buy it when it's on a decent sale. As everyone else has said, this game is Hades: if you've played your fill of that game and want a different but weaker in every aspect clone, Warm Snow is your ticket. The concept is strong, the parts are all here, but the polish is completely lacking.

Part of this is a translation problem, without a doubt.As the player, you'll have an impossible time telling how different abilities actually interact with each other. Are bonuses multiplicative? Additive? Who knows. There isn't a player profile with numbers, the tooltips are inadequate, and abilities have unexpected results. Planning your build is replaced by praying your interpretation is approximately true. (It won't be, half the time.)

Even beyond the lack of a profile and adequate English explanations, the game suffers from major balance issues. In Hades, you need the grind to win. Winning was an excruciatingly hard process. Here, some combinations are so completely, senselessly broken you'll win without effort. I facerolled the entire game on perhaps my sixth attempt - after dying to the first major boss every other time, with hardly any of the unlockables unlocked - on the basis of mechanics I couldn't possibly explain to you. But the bosses died when I hit them, so hey, victory.

If this game had been beta-tested and tweaked for even a few more months, it could be quite solid. The controls are tight, and the developers brought some interesting ideas to the table. As it exists, it scratches an itch left by an infinitely-stronger predecessor, but fails to stick core expectations; a stellar roguelite experience demands an interface by which a player can plan. Warm Snow is a fun, random crapshoot of affixes and abilities, but it lacks replayability due to loss of control. Having beaten the game once (by sheer chance), I have little desire to return and find out which builds I think should work don't (for no explicable reason), and which random ones do lethal damage due to ???.
Fun hack and slash roguelite. There's a lot to unlock and try, and the core gameplay is very fluid and fast, which I prefer. I'd recommend if you'd like a new reoguelite to sink your teeth into.

Alright finally beat the game once, took a while. The game is absolutely amazing aesthetically and the build variety within it is super neat, you unlock different "classes" from beating the bosses each playing differently, and each having 2 subclasses, and within each class there are skill modifying passives you can get combined with the generic ones shared across all classes. Other than that there are randomly rolled weapons with a base weapon type that buffs you if you get a specific combination of items, like turning your throwing knife item into frost damage and increasing the damage if you have another item for it. 

The game falls into the middle ground of "between run progression is too strong" and "you can win without", they range from straight up just boosting damage by 30%, to doubling healing, to adding other effects, i almost beat the last boss with some 20 statpoints out of 100 ish unlocked, but couldnt heal anymore due to running out of healing items since i only had 2, which i could have had 4 or 5, on top of a free once per run revive if i had more points, so at moments like those it can feel frustrating to lose since you know you could have won, not by being better, but by having more stats. Rough estimate if for all of them would be doubling health and doubling damage atleast, on top of the entire utility tree.


One of the downsides to the game as it stands right now though is that the english translation is... rough. If you play some of them becomes more obvious, but some of them are still quite confusing, such as "backdraft" being ignite, and "sheath" being your recall sword ability. 

Outside of a few bugs though the game has been super smooth, only one i got was the boss kept attacking after it was dead but i could still run to the next area, so it was just unfortunate. Some have had trouble with bosses being immortal, but so far havent managed to run into it yet.

Regardless of issues i might have i keep coming back and i keep seeing a ton of ways to build a character, with each class playing differently and there being real choices and consequences in your skill selection such as 300% more damage done but also double damage taken, or super tanky stats but cant dash. If you are looking for a game where you can bite your teeth into optimizing a specific build then this is for you.

Overall a blast for the first 30 minutes I've been in. 

The skills are neat, has your standard skill trees like in Gunfire Reborn. There's a ton of options for builds and weapon customization. For instance you do extra damage with "drunk" and if your build has fire in it, you start doing DOT damage while they're drunk and on fire. That made me laugh. 

The boss fights are fun, some have some surprising mechanics but in the beginning it's easy and the difficulty only goes up from there until you wonder what the hell just hit you.

I've only played one run so far, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. Fundamentally it is a roguelike (roguelite) dungeon crawler along the lines of The Binding of Isaac or, more accurately to its clear inspiration, Hades. The gameplay feels very much like Hades, in a good way, and with plenty of tweaks to make it stand out as its own game. The combat is tight and responsive, enemies generally have good, clear telegraphs for attacks, and the upgrades are uniquely versatile.  

To speak on the upgrade system, any of the upgrade items you pick up during a run can be applied to one of your four "inventory" slots. Depending on which slot you choose, that item will bestow a completely different effect. In one slot it might grant you an active skill which allows you to poison enemies, while in a different slot it will buff poison damage from other sources. This means that you must not only choose which items you want to bring with you, but also exactly which of their effects you want to apply. Even in only one run I have already seen the intricate web of decisions this can lead to.  

As for art, the game looks wonderful. The enemies, characters, and environments are all beautiful (or hideous and horrifying, when they need to be) and I very much enjoyed just looking at the game. It's colorful and creative and all around fun.  

The only real criticism I have so far is that not everything is fully translated. I don't expect English voice acting, but I would like to know what the big shopkeep lady is rambling about, just with some subtitles.
